Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(2) Summary

One of the challenges of modern Microservices Architecture is a less centralized locus of design and development. Nurturing a more decentralized way of designing, developing, and evolving services is one of the key value propositions of microservices, and thus this challenge should not be perceived as a "problem to be fixed." Instead, the approach should be to look at a way of how services can be more loosely coupled, so that the traditionally more centralized models of design and evolution can be replaced with techniques that are better suited in the new environment. At a high level, it is all about reducing the need and the desire to control and guide teams in a traditional command-and-control way. Instead, the goal is to empower teams to make their own decisions about design and evolution, but to give them the tools and the support that help them to succeed. This presentation looks at some of the typical differences between a more traditional design/evolve cycle, and one where architecture takes on a more fluid and flexible role.

Why Microservices? Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(11) Microservices and APIs

  • APIs are a way to loosely coupled component interfaces
    • APIs allow removing dependencies between components
    • Loose coupling is influenced by a variety of design factors
  • Microservices are a way to loosely coupled component implementations
    • Microservices allow implementing services with fewer constraints
    • APIs can be anything but some landscape coherence makes sense
  • Microservice Architecture means trying to optimize the balance
    • Avoid slowing down teams because of constrained design options
    • Help teams to be faster by assisting their design/implementation efforts


Why Microservices? Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(12) There is no "Microservice APIs"

The Six V's of Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(14) 6 MSA V Executive Summary

  • Variety
  • Volume
  • Velocity
  • Visibility
  • Vulnerability
  • Volatility


The Six V's of Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(15) Variety

  • Increased diversity of the API and implementation landscape
  • Manage API descriptions in extensible ways
    • Your API ecosystem will evolve and new types will appear


The Six V's of Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(16) Volume

  • More services are created because there is less ceremony
  • Make API management part of general MSA automation efforts
    • API landscaping should focus on scalable methods


The Six V's of Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(17) Velocity

  • Services change more often (if required) because of agile practices


The Six V's of Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(18) Visibility

  • It should be easy to find and use services as building blocks for new ones


The Six V's of Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(19) Vulnerability

  • Support service security so that teams can focus on value creation


The Six V's of Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(20) Volatility

  • Service decentralization needs different dependency management models


How? Continuous Architecting!

Outline (How? Continuous Architecting!)

How? Continuous Architecting! Erik Wilde (@dret): Changing APIs at Microservices Scale

(22) API your APIs

  • Expose design-time and runtime API information in the API
    • Design-time allows automation of API landscape overview
    • Runtime allows automation of API landscape status
  • Follow robust extensibility principles [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2016/04/robust-extensibility.html] for these API APIs
    • Meaningful Core: Start with a simple but useful scenario
    • Extension Points: Think about how scenarios might evolve
    • Processing Model: Be clear about how extensions are handled
